name: Methylphenidate (Ritalin)
summary: A short-acting central nervous system stimulant used to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and narcolepsy.
description: Methylphenidate (Ritalin) is a CNS stimulant that increases dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain by blocking their reuptake into presynaptic neurons. It is indicated for ADHD in children and adults and narcolepsy in adults. Ritalin is an immediate-release formulation, usually dosed multiple times per day due to its short duration of action.

contraindications: Tics or family history of Tourette's syndrome

sections.text: Blocks norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake into presynaptic neurons, increasing their synaptic availability; rapid onset and short duration.

adult.adhd: Start 10 mg twice daily, before breakfast and lunch; may increase by 10 mg increments weekly; usual range 20–60 mg/day in 2–3 divided doses
adult.narcolepsy: 20–30 mg/day in 2–3 divided doses; maximum 60 mg/day

sections.pediatric: Start 5 mg twice daily, before breakfast and lunch; may increase by 5–10 mg increments weekly; maximum 60 mg/day

items: Oral solution: 5 mg/5 mL, 10 mg/5 mL

serious: sudden cardiac death in patients with structural heart abnormalities

sections.black_box: High potential for abuse and dependence.
other: May increase blood pressure and heart rate—monitor regularly
Risk of exacerbating psychiatric symptoms such as psychosis or mania

items: BP and HR at baseline and periodically

sections.pregnancy: Use if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant for irritability or poor weight gain
sections.geriatrics: Limited data; use with caution due to cardiovascular risks

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction not typically required, but abrupt discontinuation may cause fatigue or depression.

items: Often requires 2–3 daily doses for full day coverage
Last dose should be taken before late afternoon to avoid insomnia
Switching to extended-release formulations may improve adherence
